Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When the humidities flow over the canal of the lung, and especially when it is with a cold temperament, then it is necessary that the weak one be evacuated first with solvent medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize it in a nostril at the root of the throat in a depressed place: and beware, lest you penetrate with the cauterization to the throat, nor into the skin, except for a little of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize it with a cautery at the junction of the neck on the last vertebra, applying it from below: and let the cautery be a moderate one, in the manner that has been described before.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has been described before, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the method of cauterizing in diseases of the Lung and Cough.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and disease of the lung are due to cold humidities, and the patient has no fever, nor phthisis, nor an old disease: then cauterize him with two cauteries above the armpit in depressed, gentle, empty places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And cauterize with another on the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and let the cautery be a reed one, according to the form that has been described before.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you need to cauterize by pricking with a cautery, which is called a Point, whose form has been described before in the pricking of ear pain: and let the points be from thirty points up to almost sixty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with what has been described before, until it is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let the cautery have three branches, according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	For it is alleviated by this cauterization, when you make with it one of three cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the method of cauterizing for a sprain, in the dislocation of the shoulder.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the joint is dislocated due to an excess of humidity, and it does not return to its place immediately after its dislocation, until it becomes accustomed to returning from its dislocation, then it becomes dislocated by a slight movement, which occurs as we have already testified, then you ought to reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then let the patient lie on his back, or on his healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then elevate the cut which is inside the Titillici upwards with the fingers of your left hand and if the joint becomes dislocated inwards.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then hold the cauterization iron with two fingers.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its shape is like this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the cut until it penetrates to the other side and the figure of cauterization appears with four cauterizations.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when the cauterization is done with a cauterizer having three fingers, then the figure of cauterization is made with six cauterizations: and they are fingers according to the subtlety attempted.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of a cauterizer having three fingers.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added to it in this manner, then there are eight cauterizations.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then put on the cauterization ground pork with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the weakened part adhere to quietness, so that it is not moved for a period of time, until it becomes strong.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upwards and it rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a cauterizer for the shoulder or with many punctures.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened, and the moisture is removed: and the weak part is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the method of cauterizing the Stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter 28.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When many colds and moistures occur in the Stomach, until they extract it from its complex and multiply the catarrhs to it, and frequent modes of curation, and do not strengthen: then it is necessary that the weak one lies on his back, and stretches out his legs, and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauterizations, one cauterizer under the cochlear of the breast, the size of one finger, with the shoulder cauterizer, and two cauterizations below by the two sides of one cauterizer, until the triangular figure of the cauterizations appears.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And let it be extended between both so that they do not come together when they produce pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be the quantity of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauteries be according to this form without addition, and if you use a large cautery on the middle of the stomach according to this form, and let the cautery that makes this cautery be one according to the figure of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking him who trembles at this cautery, and it is, that you mark on the stomach a point according to the quantity that you use with the encaustic, then cauterize it with the cautery of the point, then cure it with the curation which preceded until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the method of cauterizing a cold liver.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When there is pain in the liver from cold and moisture, or from a gross flatulence, until it goes out from its natural passage, and the weak one is treated with what we have said, and does not profit from it: then it is necessary that the weak one breathe on his neck, and you mark with encaustic three cauteries according to this figure, and the same quantity on the lower liver below the hypocondriac region, where the elbow of a man penetrates: and let the space that is between each cauterium be according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cauterium be straight in length according to the body: and do not press your hand with the cauterium much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of what is burned be from the thickness of the skin, the quantity of its half not added, and let the weak one stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If however he is not standing, then let him be lying, who has already extended his legs and lifted up his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of a cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you to cauterize these cauterizations with a knife cautery, when there is subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And beware, that you do not proceed to the extreme in cauterization, and the thickness of the entire skin is burned, where the entire body is burned, and it penetrates to the intestines: for the skin there is delicate, therefore know that.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the method of cauterizing apostemes of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When there occurs an exit wound, and you want to know if that apostema is in the flesh of the liver or in its tunic: then if it is in the flesh of the liver, a weak pain and heaviness without sharpness invade: and if it is in the tunic of the liver, with pain there is vehement sharpness: and you see already that it has wearied its physicians with treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is necessary therefore that the weak man breathes upon his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then figure the place of the apostema with a searing heat: then ignite a cautery which is similar to a hot branding iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize with it one cautery, until the entire skin is burned, and it penetrates to the siphac, until all the pus comes out: then treat it with the treatment of exit wounds, until it is healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not necessary that this species of cautery be used, except by one whose study in the art of medicine is prolonged: and through whose hands these diseases run with experimentation many times: then indeed he dares to undertake an operation of this kind.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But to leave it, with me it is better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of Pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said, a cautery with the roots of aristolochia for a cold Pleurisy in this manner.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And it is, that you take from the roots of the dry long aristolochia, one root which is longer and found on it, and is as thick as a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then submerge it in oil: and ignite it in the fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery at the place which is between the junction of the jaw and the neck, and with two small cauteries slightly sloping downwards towards the part that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also at the place which is between the fifth and sixth ribs sloping downwards towards the back a little: and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries on the back: one at the place which is between the two shoulder blades: and two cauteries on the two sides of the chest, below the cautery that is between the two shoulder blades.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And it is not necessary that you press your hand with the cautery, unless it be on the manifest skin with a foul smell.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And certain ancients have said that there are men who use a cautery of iron similar to a probe: and they ignite it, and insert it inside between the ribs, until it reaches with it to the apostema itself, and the pus comes out: as we have said concerning the apostema of the pleura.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with a cautery there is fear that either the weak person dies immediately, or a fistula occurs in the place, for which there is no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	On the method of cauterizing the Spleen Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the disease of the spleen, with that which we have said concerning the cure in the division of diseases, and your treatment is not effective, then a cautery on it is according to three methods, all of which are correct.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of these one is, that you make three or four cauteries along the length of the spleen according to the figure of the cauteries of the pleura, whose figure has preceded.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between the cautery a quantity of the thickness of a finger, or a little more.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the method of the cautery be that which we have described for the cautery of the liver equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery, and let the patient lean weakly on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another method of cauterization is: as we have said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder, to hold two rods of a fiery cautery, and to raise the skin which is along the spleen, where the weak left elbow penetrates: and let your elevation be such that you raise the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then insert two ignited rods well in, until you penetrate the skin with them from the other side: then extract the cautery: thus four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with another cautery having three rods.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then take care that the cautery, after you apply it, discharges pus for many days: for it is more conducive to healing than all the other things which have preceded in the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the method of cauterizing in Dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall into a case of dropsy, except for a proper ascites.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat a case of dropsy with the methods of cure which we have described in the division, and the cure is not effective, then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, and one cautery on the stomach, and another cautery on the liver, and one on the spleen, and two cauteries on the back between the spine, and one along the breast, and another along the stomach: and let the quantity of the depth of the cautery be near to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then diminish the open cauterization so that it emits pus over a long period.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And the weak should not be evacuated from the cure after the cauterization with what is necessary so that two intentions are added to it, and the healing will hasten with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery with which the belly is cauterized should be a clamp, according to the form that preceded it: and that with which the back is cauterized, an olive, according to the form that preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the method of cauterizing the feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter 34.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they have apostemed in a hydropic and are filled with citrine water, it is necessary to cauterize on the back of the foot in the nocturnal, which is between the ear and the ring finger: and raise your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then raise your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the citrine water will flow out, and let the cautery be according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on the two legs two cauteries on each leg, and let the cautery be made with the extremity of the knife's edge: and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one below the knee and another lower than that, around the middle of the leg: and on the entire thigh make two cauteries: and diminish the open cautery without cure for a long time: so that some water flows out from it: then cure it with the remaining things that we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the method of cauterizing for the relief of the belly.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter 35.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a solution of the belly from cold and humidities, until it debilitates the retaining and digestive virtues, which are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with modes of cure, and not healed: and you see the weak one tolerating the cautery of abundant virtue, then cauterize it with a great cautery on its stomach, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with the circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries around the navel, with a subtle clamp cautery: and a great cautery above the alcatin above the hump, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see excessive humidity and the weak patient tolerating it, then cauterize it with a cauterizer over the chest, and cauterize everything with it: and perhaps you will add two small cauterizations over the stomach near the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a advancing treatment, whose benefit does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are from gross humors, cold, or corrupt humidities, and they are treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment is not effective: then cauterize with three cauterizations above the lower vertebra of the back under the alumidei for a short time in a triangular fashion, and cauterize under the navel almost two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled, and his food is not digested, and you see his face breaking out in a rash, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cauterizer, according to what has preceded: and cauterize over his liver, and another over his spleen, with a cauterizer of the spine: and apply the open cauterization for some time: then treat him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing the warts after their removal.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you remove a wart, then apply a cauterizer that resembles a radish.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then insert the ignited thing into the removed wart: and with your hand, until the cauterizer penetrates to the opening of the vein, from which blood runs: do it once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If there are many warts, then cauterize each one with a cauterizer according to what we have described.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then treat them with that which is beneficial to them from ointments, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cauterization on the shoulder, it is more so in the joint.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	Of the method of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the weak one does not undergo the cutting and operation that we described in its own place, and is deterred by it, perhaps he will be healed with a cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore a fistula occurs to someone, and it becomes chronic, pus runs out of it, and corrupted moistures.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	It is fitting therefore that which ought to be done, that you should examine it with a subtle probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then recognize the quantity of its depth with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then apply a cautery iron, which is similar to a probe.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then insert the ignited instrument itself into the fistula and the quantity in which the nail entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery over it, until all those corrupted bodies are burnt, once, or twice, or thrice, according to the quantity of your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And beware of the burning of the nerve, if it is there, or of the great vein: or if the fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then beware of all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do that, unless when the fistula is in a fleshy place: and you think, that it is not penetrating.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then treat the place until it is healed.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If however the place becomes closed, and matter is cut off from it, and it remains thus for a long time: then know that it is already healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if matter is not cut off from it, then know that it is penetrating, or in its depth there is a corrupted opening, or something like that: the reminder of which will come in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When there is pain in the kidneys from cold or from gross flatulence and it becomes weaker because of that, then it is necessary to cauterize it on the almethen over the kidneys themselves, to cauterize each kidney with a cauterizing iron, whose description has preceded.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we will cauterize it a second time on that same almethen.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Three linear scars will appear.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore, the last ones will be more in the flank.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness in the bladder and softening from cold and humidity, until it does not retain weak urine, then cauterize it on the lower part of the pubic area over the bladder, where the hairs of the pubic area begin, and cauterize with one cauterizing iron on the right side of the pubic area, and another on the left side: and let the length of that cauterization be according to the quantity of a knot of the thumb: and cauterize it with a lower back cauterizing iron, or two cauterizing irons, if you judge it necessary: and let it be according to what has preceded, the cauterizing iron of the clavicle.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the uterus.
Caput XLI.	Chapter 41.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When there is cold and humidity in the uterus, and it is prevented from conception because of that, and its menses are corrupted, and the provocation of them is delayed, and pain happens to it at the time of their arrival, then it is necessary to cauterize with three cauterizing irons around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and cauterize over the lower abdomen with a back cauterizing iron, or two cauterizing irons: and let the cauterizing iron be of the clavicle.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the method of cauterizing an ankle in a state of dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter 42.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous humidities are poured out to the ankle's box, and they become the cause of its exit from its place: and the sign of this is that one leg is longer than the other when they are compared together: and the place of dislocation is found vacant in it.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	It is necessary therefore that you cauterize the weak place above the ankle's box with a similar circular cautery: after which you mark with a branding iron around the circumference of the box, as it turns out: and so that the box itself falls in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the cautery be one whose shape was described previously in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	Which if this cautery is not present to you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive-tree cautery: and let the depth of the cautery be according to the quantity of the thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then treat it, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterizing for sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter 43.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the box of the ankle, and the causes of it are cold and humidities: and the weak place is treated with what we have said in the division, and the treatment does not work, and it becomes worse: then it is necessary that you release the weak place from gross humors with fetid pills, or with artificial pills, and similar things.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cautery in it is according to two methods: either a cautery with adhering medicines, or a cautery with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cautery with fire is according to many methods.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	Of which one is, that you cauterize above the ankle's box with three triangular cauteries, according to this shape.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make for them a good depth, or a bad one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And let the space that is between all cautery be of the quantity of the thickness of the finger, and let the cautery be of olive.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes, however, the cautery is made in the middle on top of the head of the same ankle.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	There are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you apply the cautery with a circle, whose shape has preceded in the dislocation of the ankle, to one: so that the circle contains the whole ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the entire skin.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of the cautery for sciatica, when the pain adheres to the ankle itself, and does not extend to the hip and the leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the hip and the leg, then apply the cautery with two cauteries above the hip, above the place to which that weakness points, in which is the pain, and apply your cautery above the haunch four fingers towards the wooded area for a short time: and let the cautery be knife-shaped.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	Which if the weakness indicates that the pain extends nearly to the toes of the foot, then apply the cautery there where it points with a cautery of one point, or three, or four, or more, if it needs it.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if it points to the pain being under the knee turned to the leg, then apply the cautery there with one knife-shaped cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in every cautery of yours, that you do not apply the cautery to this, so that you burn a nerve, or a large artery, and draw through it above the weakness a bad nocument, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have already seen one and another, of those who applied the cautery above the haunch, and finished in the cautery, and the leg became inflamed, until a tumor followed to the foot, and it was entirely perforated, and the entire foot was corrupted: then there occurred a loosening of the belly, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	What if the pain is in two parts at the same time, cauterize each according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And certain wise men have said regarding cauterization of the ankle, whose cauterization this is the method.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar iron instrument, the diameter of which is half a palm, and let it be at its orifice according to the thickness of a date stone, or a little less, and inside that instrument let there be a third instrument.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let the space that is between all the instruments be the size of a thumb joint, and let the instruments be open on two sides, and let their height be like a knot, or two knots, and make for them a handle from iron decently fitted to the instruments.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be ignited in the fire until it becomes red and throws off sparks: then let it be placed on a weak ankle, having reclined on the healthy side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Cauterize it therefore with three round cauterizations in one spot.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then leave it for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards apply a plaster with butter, and leave the wound open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointment, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, we have made little use of this type of cauterization, on account of the terror of its appearance, and because we find few who dare to try it.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, it is one of the good cauterizations for him who suffers it and finds its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	A cauterization with adhering medicines is to make two instruments having a perforated armlet, into which descends a rod of the door of bronze or iron, the length of a wall, and for their height there are two knots, or nearly so.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let the space that is between both be the size of a finger's thickness, and let it be open below and above, and let what they contain be joined to each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then remove it and place it on a plaster bandage, the weak lying on the healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand strongly on the plaster bandage.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles from warm water, which has been heated with fire for a short time, and hold it for an hour's quantity of time: and let the weak endure its biting and burning, for he finds the biting as fire, until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then lift your hand with the instrument, and wipe away the warm water from the entire bandage with sweet water: then leave it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put on it butter, until the blackness of the burn is removed: and leave it for several days, and pus will be cured from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is indeed the last in the treatment.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with ointments, until it is healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	What if the pain extends to the hip or the leg: make for it a plaster that contains water, according to what you did on the bandage equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of warm water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take of alkaline substance and unslaked lime each one part: grind both, and put them in a new pot, the lower part of which is perforated with one small hole, according to the quantity that the radius may enter: and put under the bottom of the pot another pot vitreous: and throw over the alkaline substance and lime sweet water, which submerges both by the finger: after which you compress it with your hand with good compression: and leave the pot until sharp water descends to the lower part of the vitreous pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then collect that water entirely, and throw it over another lime: and filter, until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	It itself will then be of strong sharpness indeed, which is administered in many operations of medicine, and in the cauterization of the remaining members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	Since it performs the operation of its own fire.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And there are medicines with which they cauterize the anch, and also such as tessie, and honey of the anacard, and lime with soap, so that both may be mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen told of a certain man from the ancients, whose cure was for the pain of the ankle and the vein of the thigh, and he declared its effectiveness to be very great.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said that it did not need another cure, and that he was healed by one remedy, until he related that he perhaps entered a bath and came out of it already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is, that it be taken from the green vitriol, and if the green is not found, let the dry, fresh one be taken, and let it be ground much with some fat, and let it be put on the ankle, where there is pain, or the leg, or in the hip, and let it be tied, and let it be left for the quantity of three hours, or as long as he feels the weakness of the heat of the application.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then let him enter into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore his body becomes very sweaty, let him enter into the sun.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain recedes and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that it is not necessary to use any cauterization with these medicines, unless after the purging of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides said that the dung of capers, when with it the vein of the thigh is cauterized, brings to it relief, and makes a cauterization in this manner.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Let wool be ground, and let it be soaked with old oil, and let it be put on the deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot, and the heel, and is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry dung of a goat and set it on fire, until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put it on a cloth and let it be, until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat that.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Do not stop doing that until the sensation on the middle and up to the ankle is penetrated and the pain subsides.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cauterization is called the cauterization of the cow.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	Of the cauterization of pain in the back.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When pain occurs in the back for many reasons, or from a fall, or from a blow, or from excessive evacuation, and similar things, from the infusion of cold and damp material: and cauterization is not applied, except in this single case, which occurs from the infusion of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after evacuation of the weak with fetid pills and similar things, so that they make on the back, where there is pain, three lines according to the width of the affected part, then mark with a cautery in each line five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity that comes from the tolerance of the weak, by virtue of which: and let the cauterization be made with cauterized points.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauterizations, with the middle clavicular cautery, according to this method.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	Of the method of cauterizing in cases of gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 45.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This sickness often happens to small infants.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of this disease in children is: that there occurs a tightening on it with shortness of breath at elevation and movement: and you find in the last vertebrae of the back and its knots, which already begins to protrude over the remaining vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When I raise that and make a use for it, then I cauterize it with a cauterizer that is a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let the cauterization take hold equally over every part of the vertebrae: and if you cauterize around the vertebrae with a pointed cauterizer two or three lines: and let the points be close to one another.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then treat the place until it is healed with what we have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you administer a cauterization on a hump that forms in a spasm of a nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterizing for gout and joint pains.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter 46.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When joint pains are from cold humidities that flow to any members of the body, then when pains occur in the feet, it is by custom of physicians to name that specifically Gout.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore gout caused by cold is treated with methods of cure and the pains are not removed, then a cauterization removes them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is that you cauterize after evacuation around the joint of the foot with many cauterizers: and let the cauterization be with an oily one.
Cuius haec est forma.	Its form is like this.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you indicate that there are points on the surface of the foot, then make them with a pointed cauterizer.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	Which if the pains ascend to the knees or other joints and it often happens, then cauterize it above every knee with three or four cauterizers on every side, with this same cauterizer of the ankle.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If however many are needed for you with this cauterizer, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cauterizer, but rather let it be to the thickness of the skin as much.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If however pains ascend to the knees and the back: then administer what we have said from cauterization in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	What if pains are in the hands only, then puncture at the circuit of the elbow joints, as two lines turn.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If however there remains from pains in the fingers, then puncture them, above every joint a puncture, and above the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If however pains ascend after days to the elbows or to the shoulders, then cauterize both from every side.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the weak from a good regime, from the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if a good regime is made, and phlegm is evacuated, it will be healed with the help of God by this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of rupture.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter 47.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and intestine descends, or a cyst to the testicle, and it is beginning nearby: then it is necessary to prescribe to the weak that they abstain from food on that day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use laxatives, so that feces may descend from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back: and prescribe to him, that he hold his breath, until it comes out, or the cyst appears, or intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with a cauterizing iron under the rupture on the bone of the hip, with a mark whose extremities are similar to the middle of a circle towards the upper parts of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then ignite the cauterizing iron, which has this form, until it becomes white, and throws out sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine or cyst to its concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the servant put his hand on the place, so that the intestine does not come out: and you have already opened between the thighs of the weak, and placed under it a pillow, and one servant over the thighs of him, and another over his chest who holds the hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then apply the cautery on the same sign, your hand with the cautery standing upright.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it until you bring it to the mouth, or turn it with it twice, if you have not brought it to the mouth at first.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the intestine's exit at the time of your cauterization, lest you burn it, and an issue comes through that above the weak or mortified place, or great malignity.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not bring the cautery to the mouth, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is fitting that the cautery for infants be subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat with the remaining ointments, until it is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the weak one lie on his back for forty days, until the wound is closed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is fitting that you put a nourishment for it for the length of time of its cure, which will soothe its stomach: so that the intestine does not come out through the wound and vomiting.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to get up after forty days, then administer a properly made bandage, and let him hold it for forty more days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should be kept from labor, and from the filling of food and drink, and vehement voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regime, thus will he be healed with a complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the cure of hernias with an incision in its own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When however hernias occur in the remaining abdomen, and are beginning, and it is seen that they do not increase, then cauterize the hernia with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let what is applied be about one third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then treat it with what we have said: and it will not increase.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some of the first have said: that a hernia should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with a cautery, and a line is placed which runs along the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line to the lower one.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And put your hand in the middle with the cautery on the hip.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the method of cauterizing for pains caused by a fall or a blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter 48.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain members from a fall or a blow, and the pain persists for a long time, and treatment with medicines is of no benefit, then it is necessary to cauterize with a pointed cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery of each member be a second cautery according to its size, and its smallness, and its weakness, and its strength, and the location of the twisting and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed by the first cautery, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat it over the same cautery.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	For it is a habit of these pains that they are transferred from one member to the one that is nearest to it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Wherefore it is necessary to follow them with a cautery until the weak part is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the method of cauterizing for leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Lepers are sometimes helped by a very strong cautery.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the type of leprosy that occurs due to the putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: when therefore you want to cauterize it, consider it.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore the leprosy is beginning, and you have treated it with what we said in the division, and it does not decrease, nor stop: and there is a weak spot that corruption has comprehended over its whole complexion: then cauterize him on the head with five cauteries: one on the middle of the head at the knot, and a second below that towards the forehead at the end of the hair, and two above the two horns, and one behind on the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And finally touch your hand briefly with the cautery, until it impresses a small mark on the mouth, and the cortices will dislocate from it: so that the expiration of gross vapors is eased from it, and cauterize with the cautery also above the same spleen, according to what has proceeded.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if the leprosy has already spread over the weak part, and appears manifestly: then it is necessary that you cauterize with those cauteries, which we mentioned in the beginning, and cauterize above the extremity of the nose, and with two cauteries above the two jaws, and with two cauteries above the vertebrae of the neck, and six above the vertebrae of the back, and one large one above the region of the tail near the end of the spine and one above it, in the same flank: and two above the elbows: namely one above each elbow, and two above the knees: one above each knee, and two above the shoulders, and two above the elbows, and two above the tenderness of his chest: and cauterize it above every joint, of the joints of his fingers and toes: and cauterize above every heel of his feet, and the soles of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves that are above the heel, lest you burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes cauterization is performed with a cautery on the bone of the chest, and another on the bone of the stomach, and another on the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you apply the cautery, the greater is the benefit, and the more it helps.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the weak person does not find pain in the cautery, as the healthy ones do: because his body is already numbed.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that the cauteries be of a size and smallness according to the limbs and joints: according to what has preceded from the species of iron instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat with a cauterization made from powder of the herb with honey, and continue the treatment until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the method of cauterizing for a stupor.
Caput L.	Head of the sick person
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When any member is numb, and it is treated with medicines, and oils, and plasters, and it is not healed, then cauterize the numb member with cauterizations, according to what its size deserves or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cauterization penetrate briefly into the thickness of the skin.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with an ointment until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when the cauterization is applied for a numbness that occurs to the hand and foot, at the joints of the back near where the nerves exit, which move that member: and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	Indeed, let no one presume to do this except one who is wise in the anatomy of the members and the exit of the nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On the method of cauterizing for Baras.
Caput LI.	Chapter 51.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When the Baras becomes chronic and nothing from the ingenuity of medicine is effective for it: then cauterize over it with a deep cauterization briefly, according to the quantity of the thickness of the skin, until the whiteness is removed and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with powder of the herb and lentils with rose oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and blood of a pigeon, and blood of a hyrundine: let each be one part: mix all these things, and apply them to a cloth, and adhere to the place, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the method of cauterizing for a Cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter 52.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When the Cancer is beginning and you want to restrain it: then cauterize it with a circular cauterization around its circumference, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said that a cauterization should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	It does not seem to me: because I fear that it will become an ulcer, and I have already seen that happen many times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around it with a circle, as we have said, or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the method of cauterizing in cases of boils.
Caput LIII.	Chapter 53.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has a boil and it is delayed in maturing, either because of the excess matter that makes it, or because of the weakness of the patient, when he is decrepit and has little blood, or because of the time and the need to hasten the maturation of the boil, then cauterize around it with many small cauteries, making many punctures.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then leave it alone.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it will hasten the maturation by itself.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you want to make a perforation of it with a cautery, then ignite the cautery, whose shape is this.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the boil, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be made from that which follows, being weak, so that the flow of pus may be alleviated.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then treat it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the method of cauterizing for a corroding sore.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corroding sore is nothing but a corruption that moves in a member and corrodes it: just as fire devours dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If you see a corroding sore in a place that can tolerate a cautery with fire, then prepare many cauteries, small and large, according to what is suitable for the place where the corroding sore is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it on every side until you eradicate the entire corruption, and none of it remains in any way.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then touch the same for three days, and apply over the cauterized place burnt sulfur with oil, until all eschars are eradicated, and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then heal it with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days sound flesh is born without corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then repeat the cautery over that which remains of the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the corroding is treated whenever with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	It itself rises in place of the cautery.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	But indeed the cautery with fire is of quicker relief: and I have already spoken of its cauterization with sharp medicine in division: therefore take it there when you need it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the method of cauterizing in hammer-like tumors and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter 55.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	It often happens that this sickness occurs in the lower parts of the feet: and it is a coarse, foul thing which harms the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed the cautery for them is in two ways: cautery with fire, and cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	But as for the one with fire, it is like a hollow cautery of a falcon's feather, which is made from iron, according to the quantity that the hammer contains on all sides: and let its edges be subtle.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then apply it ignited upon the hammer-like tumor.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with the cautery around the hammer-like tumor, until the cautery penetrates to the depth of the tumor: and leave it for three days, until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then plaster it with crushed forest herbs, ground with salt: and leave the plaster on it during the night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be eradicated from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then treat the place with a generating ointment of flesh until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	What if they are not turned and often occur on the surface of the body, especially on the hands and feet: then administer to them cauterization with hot water: and it is, that you take a small tube made of bronze, or iron, or from a feather of a vulture: and put it on the nail, or the ulcer.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then throw into the tube a small quantity of hot water: hold your hand, and you turn it with compression of your hand for a short time, so that the edge of the tube is impressed on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds a way to the depth, to the root of the nail: and let the weak one wait for an hour on the biting of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for the nail is eradicated with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Do this with them one after another, until you come to all of them that are on the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then treat them after they have been eradicated, with that which generates flesh from ointments.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the method of cauterizing for Tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 56.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.
