Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken in the division of the species of cancer, and how it is the way to cure it with medicines: and to beware of it with the cure of it with iron, so that it does not become ulcerated: and we have spoken of cancer generated in the matrix, and caution in its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that whenever cancer is in a place where its eradication is possible, such as cancer which is in the breasts or in the hip, and similar members located for extraction of all of it, especially when it is beginning and small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When however it becomes old and is large, it is not suitable to approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I myself was not able to heal any of them: nor have I seen anyone before me who has approached that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation on it, when it is located as we have said, is to precede and dissolve the weakness with black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then phlebotomize it if you find it with a manifest fullness.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the weakness for preparation, in which it will be treated with operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then apply to the cancer ointments that are suitable for it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterward press it from every part with the skin, according to the scrutation, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, but express the place, and wipe away all gross blood with your hand, or with any instrument that is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if a profuse flow of blood is contrary to you from the incision of an artery or vein: then cauterize the vein, until the blood is stopped.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remainder of the treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the treatment of Dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter 54.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have now explained in the division of the species of Dropsy, and how the collection of water is made: and the signs of each species, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is treated with iron, is not but the species of ascites alone: and it does not approach with iron the species of tympanitis: nor the species of hyposarca inwardly: for that is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this species of Dropsy, tympanitis, with medicines, and your medication has not been effective: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if debility has already befallen the weak person, or if there is another infirmity with it besides Dropsy: such as if there is with it a cough, or a loosening of the stomach, and things similar to these: then beware that you do not treat him with iron: for that is to be feared.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see the weak person of overflowing strength, and there is no sickness with it besides Dropsy alone: and he is neither a child nor an old man: then the method of operation on him is, that you should lift up the weak person standing between your hands, and your assistant behind him presses out his stomach with his hand, forcing water to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spiney spongy bone, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	It has two sharp parts, is long, with a pointed extremity like the Spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But in it let there be something of shortness little by little, so that you do not transpierce with it during the operation to the intestine, and wound it.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is a generation of dropsy from the side of the intestines, then it is necessary that you should lengthen with the section from the navel by the quantity of three fingers, downwards directly above the chest.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If indeed the generation of dropsy is because of liver sickness, then let your section be on the left from the navel by three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	And if the generation of it is because of the spleen, then let the section be on the right side: and it is not necessary also that the section be on the side above which the sick person wants to lie, so that the superfluities do not run to that weak place.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	Then pierce with an instrument the whole skin.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	Then insert into that section, and raise your hand with the spatula between the skin, and rub, as if you are scraping it out: and let the quantity which is scraped out be the quantity of a nail, or about that.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	Then scrape through, until the spatula reaches the empty place: and it is the place of water.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	Then extract it, and insert into the hole an instrument, whose form is this.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	And it is similar to a cannula: made from silver, or copper, or gold, clean and polished: which has a small hole in its lower part, and on its sides are three holes, two on one side and one on the other side: and its end is cut, according to the manner of cutting a reed, as you see: on its upper end is a handle.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	When the instrument penetrates the water, then it itself descends immediately on the instrument, and thus evacuates from the water at once half the quantity.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	Since if you evacuate from it more than is necessary, then perhaps the weak person dies at once through resolution of his animal spirit: or a fainting fit that approaches death befalls him.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	Evacuate from it according to the quantity of its virtue, and according to what the dispositions of the weak person signify to you from the virtue of his pulse, and from his goodness.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	Then withdraw the instrument, and retain the water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	Which is, that it is retained at once on account of the skin which retains the opening that is above the sifac: about which I have spoken, that you should perforate it according to that method.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	Then repeat the instrument on the second day, if you see the weak person tolerate it: and withdraw also from the water a small quantity.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	Do that for several days without fear, and guard yourself from error: until there does not remain from the water except a little.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	If you are afraid for the weak person, and you leave a large amount from the water: then treat it with burial in hot sand, and with much sweat in bath and sun, and await its thirst: and treat it with medicines evacuative, until it is healed: and cauterize above the stomach, and liver, and spleen, after extraction of the water: according to what I have spoken in that which preceded.
¶ De cura infantium qui nascuntur locis urinae eorum non perforatis.	On the treatment of infants who are born with their urinary places not perforated.
Caput LV.	Chapter 45.
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco.	When any infant goes out from the womb of its mother, and the head of its bladder is not perforated, or the opening is narrow, or it is not in its proper place.
Oportet ergo succurrere cum perforatione eius statim cum nascitur cum Spatumili subtili ualde, secundum hanc formam.	It is necessary therefore to help with the perforation of it at once when it is born with a very sharp and fine spatula, according to this method.
Deinde pone in foramine clauum subtilem ex plumbo, et liga ipsum: et tene ipsum tribus diebus, aut quatuor.	Then put in the hole a thin nail made of lead, and tie it: and leave it for three days, or four.
Quando ergo uult urinam emittere, remoueatur, et mingat.	When the skin is raised to pass urine, it should be removed, and wiped.
Deinde reduc ipsum.	Then reduce it.
Et si tu non ponis plumbum, iam possibile est, ut urina quae incedit super locum, non permittat ipsum claudi.	And if you do not put in the lead, it is possible that the urine which enters on the place, will not allow it to close.
Ille autem cuius foramen est strictum, medicatur cum plumbo, sicut diximus, diebus multis, donec amplificetur.	He whose hole is narrow, is treated with lead, as we have said, for many days, until it is enlarged.
Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	Those however in whom the hole is not in its proper place, are injured.
Quod est, quia ex eis qui nascitur, foramen est apud finem capitis uirgae: quare non potest mingere ad anteriora, donec eleuat uirgam manu sua ad superiora.	That is, because among those who are born with it, the hole is at the end of the virga: wherefore she cannot urinate to the front, unless she lifts the virga with her hand upwards.
Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	And there is no generation for her, because the sperm cannot pass to the womb according to the right direction: and it is a foul and grievous disease.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	And the method of operation for that is, that the weak one is placed on her back.
Deinde extende caput uirgae eius manu tua sinistra extensione uehementi, et incide caput capitis uirgae ex loco priapi, cum acumine, aut spatumili acuto: sicut est incisio calami, aut sicut tu radis aliquid, ut medium eius ueniat simile capiti uirgae: et ut cadat foramen in medio secundum quod oportet.	Then extend the head of her virga with your left hand with vigorous extension, and cut the head of the head from the place of the priapus, with a needle, or a sharp spatula: as is the incision of a reed, or as you peel something, so that the middle of it comes to resemble the head of the virga: and so that the hole falls in the middle according to what is proper.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	And beware for yourself during the operation of a flow of blood.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	For that thing has happened many times.
Oppone ergo ei cum eo quod abscindit sanguinem, et cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	Apply to it therefore that which stops the blood, and cure the wound, until it is healed.
¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	On the matters concerning Albucasis which occur on the foreskin and head of the virga, and the corruption, blackness, and adhesion.
Caput LVI.	Chapter 6
Multotiens accidunt istae Albather in uirga, et est eminentia carnis foedae.	These things often happen to the albather on a branch, and it is an eminence of rotten flesh.
Et ex ea alia est maligna, et alia non maligna.	And some of them are malignant, and some of them are not malignant.
Non malignam ergo oportet ut suspendas cum uncino subtili, et abscindas eam, donec mundes eam totam.	You should therefore suspend the non-malignant one with a subtle hook, and cut it off, until you cleanse it completely.
Deinde pone super eam cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio.	Then put on it a plaster submerged in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud cum unguento dyafinicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it after that with the dyafrincon ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si Albather est maligna, foedi coloris, tunc oportet ut administres in ea cauterium post incisionem eius et ipsius rasionem.	Which if the albather is malignant, of foul color, then you should administer to it a cauterization after the incision of it and its rasping.
Si autem Albather est in praeputio captiui, non circumcisi, et est pars Albather inter praeputium, et pars eius extra: tunc oportet ut auferas Albather, quae est intus in primis, donec quando consolidatur, tunc cura ipsum exterius: quoniam quando tu curas eam simul, non securatur praeputium quin preforetur.	If the albather is on the foreskin of an uncircumcised person, and part of the albather is inside the foreskin and part of it outside: then you should remove the albather that is inside first, until when it has consolidated, then treat the one outside: because when you treat them both at the same time, the foreskin does not heal unless it is perforated.
Et iam accidunt etiam in testiculis, et praeputio nigredo et corruptio.	And now they also occur on the testicles and a blackening and corruption of the foreskin.
Oportet ergo, ut tu concaues totum quod iam denigratum est, et quod uult corrumpi, aut iam corruptum est.	You should therefore cauterize all that has already turned black, and what will decay or is already decayed.
Deinde line super ipsum post illud cum melle quod iam concussum est cum farina corticum granatorum, et herbi tritorum cribellatorum.	Then apply on it after that a mixture of honey which has already been mixed with the flour of roasted grains and the crushed herbs of tritorage.
Deinde cura illud cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the remainder of the treatment, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra cauterium cum cauterio lunari, secundum hanc formam.	If there is a flow of blood, then administer a cauterization with lunar cauterization, according to this method.
Cauterium enim est iuuatiuum ad duas dispositiones simul, scilicet ad fluxum sanguinis, et uulnus quando corrumpitur.	For cauterization is a remedy for two conditions at the same time, namely for a flow of blood and for an ulcer when it becomes decayed.
Quod si corroditur caput uirgae, et destruitur totum in hora: tunc oportet ut intromittas in meatum priapi cannulam ex plumbo, ut mingat infirmus super eam.	Which if the head of the branch is eaten away and destroyed entirely in one hour: then you should insert into the mouth of the penis a tube made of lead, so that the weakened man urinates on it.
In adhaerentia uero praeputii cum capite uirgae, et haec quidem adhaerentia non accidit, nisi in eo cuius praeputium est sanum, et non exigitur super ipsum circumcisio: et quandoque accidit adhaerentia propter uulnus, aut apostema: oportet ergo ut excories eam cum Spatumili obtuso, donec soluatur ligamentum, et liberetur caput uirgae ab omni parte.	In the adhesion of the skin to the head of the virga, and this adhesion does not occur except in one whose virga is healthy, and it is not necessary to circumcise over it: and when adhesion occurs because of a wound or apostema, it is necessary to cauterize it with a blunt spatula until the ligament is dissolved and the head of the virga is freed from every part.
Quod si est difficile discernere ea exquisite, tunc oportet ut excories aliquid ex capite uirgae, et ex praeputio.	What is difficult to discern with exquisite care, then it is necessary to cauterize something from the head of the virga and from the prepuce.
Quod est, quia praeputium quando est subtile, fortasse perforatur propter subtilitatem suam uelociter.	What is, that the prepuce, when it is subtle, is perhaps perforated on account of its subtlety quickly.
Deinde separa inter praeputium, et caput uirgae cum panno lini subtili, qui iam madefactus est in aqua frigida, ut non adhereant iterum.	Then separate the prepuce and the head of the virga with a subtle linen cloth, which has already been soaked in cold water, so that they do not adhere again.
Deinde curetur cum uino stiptico, donec consolidetur.	Then let it be treated with styptic wine, until it is consolidated.
¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	On the purification of infants, and the cure of errors that occur to them by accident.
Caput LVII.	Chapter 57.
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	Circumcision is not a solution of continuity, like other wounds: nevertheless since it is from our operation, our will, and its use is properly in boys, it is necessary that we indicate in this operation the better method, and the easier way leading to health.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	I say therefore, that the ancients did not mention circumcision in any of their books: since they do not use it in their laws, and it is not except what we have acquired through experimentation.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	What is, that I have found the greater part of artisans and phlebotomists using purification by circumcision with a razor, and with forceps: and they use a cauterized wound, and a ligature with a thread, and an incision with a nail.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	And I have already tried all these methods, and I did not find a better purification than with forceps and a ligature with a thread.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	Since in cleansing with a lancet, the skin often escapes.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	For the skin of the prepuce has two tunics: therefore perhaps the upper skin is cut and the inner tunic remains: hence it is necessary to make an incision to cut the other, and future pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	And with the cleansing that is done by the digital method, that is, with a needle, which surgeons use, the cutting of the extremity of the member is not avoided: for perhaps it enters into its opening.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	In cleansing with a nail, perhaps the iron comes out and spoils your operation: and the skin of a child is brief by nature, and often they are born in such a way that they do not need cleansing: and I have already seen it.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	Cleansing with forceps and ligature with a thread has shown me a good experiment: for the forceps are proportional to the incision: therefore, because the sharpness that is above is as the sharpness that is below.
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	When therefore you press with your hand, the two sharpnesses are proportioned, and they cut according to one operation at one time: and there is made a compression of similar figure, containing the skin of the member from all parts, with which error does not fall in any way.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	And the method of operation is its own, that you cause to be extracted, especially a child, if it is one of those who understand for a little while, what you do not do, except that you bind the thread on its member only: and you let it go until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	Then make him rejoice and be merry in every way that is possible for you, from the fact that he receives his understanding.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	Then make him stand between your hands prepared in a standing position, and let him not be sitting: and hide the forceps in your sleeve or under your foot, so that the child does not see them at all, nor any of the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	Then insert your hand into its branch and blow on the skin and pull it upwards until the head of the branch comes out.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	Then cleanse it from the filth that has accumulated in the wound.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	Then tie the marked place with a double thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	Afterwards tie below it for a short space a second ligature.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	Then hold with your index finger, and thumb, the place of the lower ligature with good retention, and cut between the two ligatures.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	Then lift the skin upwards quickly, and extract the head of the branch.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then let the blood flow gradually (for it is better) and put powder on top: and over the powder a cloth in which vitellus of egg has been spread, mixed with good fresh rose oil: and let it remain on until the next day: and treat it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	The shape of a fork is for cleansing purposes this.
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	Let the two extremities be blunt and let them be cutting: so that the branch of the nail does not come out on them: and let the length of the two sharp edges be as the length of the two handles equally.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	The error that occurs in cleansing is: because perhaps it escapes the inner skin entirely, or a part of it at the place of the incision.
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	Therefore it is necessary that you stretch it out with your nail before the marking of the place: and cut it according to equality.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	What if you cannot hold it with your nail, then extract it with a hook, and cut it.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	If however three days have passed and what is under the branch remains inflated, marked: then let it be until the hot apostema has settled, and excise it with ease, and cut it according to that which is prepared for you: and beware of the head of the branch.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	For it will not harm him.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	Treatment is therefore with that which consolidates the wound from powders, which we have described in the treatise on powders: and if it cuts into the skin above the measure, and it goes to the upper parts, it will not harm him either.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	Treatment is therefore with that which we have said, until it is healed.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	On the extraction of retained urine from the bladder.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter 58.
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	The retention of urine in the bladder is caused by obstruction made from stone, or congealed blood, or pus, or flesh that has grown, and similar things to these which we have spoken of as methods of treatment in the division.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	And if the urine is not discharged, and you see that its retention is on account of a stone, which is already in the neck of the bladder: then it is necessary that he should be made to bend over his knees.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	Then let his feet be placed upon his back, and let him stretch out his belly from the upper part of his back, and let him tightly constrict his breathing as much as is possible for him.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	The neck of the bladder is thus compressed towards the expulsion of the stone to the back, whereupon the urine is discharged.
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	What if it is not solved with what we have said, and the thing is vehement upon the patient: then it is necessary that you administer the extraction of it with an instrument, which is called a syringe, whose form is this: let it be of silver, and let it be subtle, thin, concave like the quill of a feather in subtlety of a radius, long in likeness to one and a half palms: to which let there be a subtle pipe at its head.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	And the method of the exit of urine through it is, that you take a doubled thread, and tie at its end a wool or a cord, with a good ligature: and introduce the end of the thread into the lower part of the Syringe: and cut with forceps if anything overflows from the wool, truly introduce into the pipe with vehemence, like an Alzer.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	Then anoint the siringa with oil, or with butter, and the white of an egg: and make the weak sit upon a seat, and embrocate the vessel, and its own virga with humid oils, and olive oil, and warm water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	Then insert the siringa into the virga with ease, until it reaches the root of the virga.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	Then fold it over double from the part of the navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	Then push the siringa into it, until it reaches the bladder, and the weak person feels that it has already reached the empty space: and this is not done according to this order, unless the passage, in which it goes, is where there is a tortuosity.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	Then extend the thread with a wool slowly.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	For the catheter will follow the wool.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	Then pull it out, and make the catheter run through the urine passage: and repeat the syringe, and do not cease to do that, until the bladder is emptied, and the weak person finds relief.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	On the quality of cleansing the bladder with a Clyster.
Caput LIX.	Chapter 59.
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	When there happens to be an ulcer in the bladder, or blood congeals in it, or pus is confined in it, and one wishes to distill waters and medicines into it: then let it be done with the instrument that is called a Clyster, and this is its form.
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	For it is stopped, that is, closed.
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	And in it are three holes, two on one side and one on the other side, as you see.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	And the concave place, in which is that which pushes, should be according to the quantity that fills it without addition, until when it is pulled with it, something is attracted from the humidities: and when it is pushed, it expels far away: according to what makes the clyster, with which naphtha is projected, that is, Greek fire in the workshops of Mars.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	When I insert the instrument to project moisture into the bladder, I introduce the extremity of the catheter into the moisture, and pull with it that which pushes upwards, for the moisture is pulled into the concavity of the catheter.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	Then I introduce its extremity into the rod, according to that which we described in the syringe.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	Then I push the moisture with that which pushes it, for the moisture immediately reaches the bladder, so that the weak person feels it.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	The shape of a thin enema instrument by which the bladder is enemad.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	Let it be made from silver or gold: whose head is higher and similar to a small hook, and under that a hollow where the ligament falls.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	Then take the bladder of a goat, and put in it moisture, with which instrument you will enema the bladder.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	Then tie it between two hollows with a strong ligature and double thread: and warm that moisture a little over the fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	Then insert the extremity of the enema instrument into the rod, afterwards tighten your hand over the bladder with the moisture with a suitable pressure, until the weak person feels that the moisture has now reached the bladder.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	If however the bladder is not present to you, then take a piece of parchment, and make from it a circle, and pierce it throughout its entire roundness.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	Then insert a strong thread into those holes, as they revolve.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	Then gather the circle, as the nest is gathered: afterwards you put in it that which you use from moistures, and oils, and waters.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	Then tie it in the instrument: and do with it as you did with the bladder by expression with your hand, until the moisture reaches the bladder.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	On the extraction of a stone.
Caput LX.	Chapter 60.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	We have already spoken about the division of the species of Stone, and its cure with medicines, and I have said the difference between the Stone generated in the kidneys and bladder, and the signs of all that: and I have said the Stone in which the operation falls with the hand and incision: and there is a Stone generated in the bladder specifically: and that which is fixed on the staff: and I am narrating that with clear exposition and abbreviation.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	I say therefore, that the Stone generated in the bladder, happens most often to children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	And one of its signs is that urine comes out from the bladder similar to water in its thinness: and appears in it white sand, and the weak man rubs his staff, and labors with it, and many times it hangs.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	Then it is erected, and goes out with that, the bottom, in many of them.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	And the cure of children is easy, as long as they are up to fourteen years old.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	And it is difficult in the elderly.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	In youths, however, it is moderate, in that which is between them: and of whom the Stone is larger, the cure is easier: and if small, the care is the opposite.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	When we arrive at the cure, it is necessary first to cleanse the weak person with a clyster, which will extract all the dung that is in his intestines: for it sometimes prevents the discovery of the Stone during the examination.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	Then let the weak person be taken by the feet, and shaken, and moved to the lower parts: so that the Stone descends to the depth of the bladder, or jumps from a high place many times.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	Then make him sit prepared between your hands, and let his hands be under his hips, so that the whole bladder is inclined downwards.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	Then examine him, and feel him from the outside.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	If therefore you feel a stone in the space, then apply the proper thing at once with incision upon it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	What if it does not fall under your touch altogether, then it is necessary that you wipe the index finger with oil of the left hand, if he is a weak boy: or the middle finger if he is a young man complete: and insert it into his anus, and feel for the stone, until it stands under your finger: and turn it little by little to the neck of the bladder.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	Then press upon it with your finger, and push it to the exterior against the place of which you wish to make an incision: and instruct one assistant to press the bladder with his hand, and instruct another assistant to extend the testicles with his right hand upwards: and his other hand, that he may remove the skin which is under the testicles on the part away from the place in which the incision is.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	Then insert a spatula or knife with an incision, the shape of which is this.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	And cut in that which is between the anus and testicles, and not in the middle, to the side of the left buttock: and let the incision be above the stone, and your finger be in the anus: and let the incision be transverse, so that the exterior incision be ample, and the interior be strict, according to the quantity that it is possible for the exit of the stone from it not being larger.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	Perhaps indeed the finger which is in the anus presses the stone near the incision, and it comes out without difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	And know that because of the stone, in which there are angles and edges, its exit is made difficult on account of that.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	And from this it is smooth, like a gland, and round: and its exit is made easy.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	Therefore for those which have angles and edges, add to the incision.
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	What if it does not come out thus, then it is necessary that you apply above it: or tie above it with a device of the center, whose extremity is like a crescent moon, which ties above the stone and does not depart from it: or that you insert under it an instrument subtle, of curved extremity.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	If you cannot exceed it, then enlarge the opening a little.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	What if something of blood conquers you, cut it off with a razor.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	If there is a stone more than one, then first push the large one to the mouth of the bladder.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	Then cut on top of it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	Afterwards push a small one after that, and do similarly if there are more than two.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	What if the valve is very large, then it is ignorance to cut above it with a large incision.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	Since it happens to the weak one of two things, either that he dies, or that there is a continual dripping of urine: therefore, because the place is not consolidated at all.
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	Indeed administer the expulsion of it, until it goes out: or instruments on the fracture with forceps, until you extract it bit by bit.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	When you have completed your operation, then fill the wound with turpentine, and aloe, and dragon's blood: and bind it, and put on it a cloth soaked in oil and wine, or rose oil, and cold water: so that the hot aposteme may be seated.
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	Then let the weak one rest on his neck, and do not loosen the bandage, until the third day.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	When you then loosen it, moisten the place with water, and much oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	Then treat it with the ointment diaphenicum, and the ointment baselicum, until it is healed.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	If however there occurs in the wound a hot and corrosive aposteme, and similar things: as if blood congeals in the bladder, and urine is prohibited from it: and that is recognized by the emission of blood with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	Therefore insert your finger into the wound, and extract that blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	For if it remains, it provokes the corruption of the bladder, and its putrefaction.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	Then wash the wound with vinegar, and water, and salt: and apply all the species with what is suitable from the treatment, until it is healed.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	And it is necessary during the hours of treatment that you bind two hips, and gather, the causes of medicines which are placed on the spot.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	What if the stone is small, and it is in the flesh of the virgin, and it is fixed in it, and the urine exit is blocked: then treat it with what I will narrate before you proceed to the cutting.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	For many times indeed you will be exempt from cutting by this treatment, for I have already tested that.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	And there is, that you should take a perforator made of iron, whose form this is, triangular at the end, sharp, fixed in wood.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	Then take a thread, and bind with it the branch under the stone so that it does not return to the bladder.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	Then insert the iron perforator into the branch with ease, until the perforator reaches the stone itself: and turn the perforator with your hand on the stone little by little: and complete the perforation of it, until you make it penetrate from the other side.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	For urine will be relieved immediately.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	Then press your hand on that which remains of the stone from the outer part of the branch.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	For it itself breaks, and goes out with the urine, and the sick person is healed.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	If however this treatment is not prepared for you, because of something that prohibits it: then bind a thread below the stone, and another thread above the stone.
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	Then cut above the stone on the same branch between the two bindings.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	Then extract it.
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	Afterwards loosen the binding, and cleanse the congealed blood which forms in the wound.
Et non est necessarium ligamentum fili sub lapide, nisi ut non redeat ad uesicam: et ligamentum aliud desuper, nisi ut quando soluitur filum post egressionem lapidis, redeat cutis ad locum suum, et cooperiat uulnus: et propter illud necesse est tibi illud quando ligas filum superius, ut eleues cutem ad superiora, ut redeat apud complementum tuum, et cooperiat uulnus, sicut diximus.	And it is not necessary to tie the thread under the stone, unless so that it does not return to the bladder: and another tie above, unless when the thread is released after the removal of the stone, the skin returns to its place, and covers the wound: and because of that it is necessary for you, when you tie the upper thread, to lift the skin upwards, so that it returns according to your complement, and covers the wound, as we have said.
¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	Of the extraction of a stone from women.
Caput LXI.	Chapter 61.
Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	A stone is rarely generated in women.
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	If however it happens to any of them a stone, then the treatment is difficult, and it is prohibited because of many methods.
Vnus eorum est: quod mulier fortasse est uirgo.	One of them is: that the woman is perhaps a virgin.
Et secundus est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem quae detegat seipsam medico, quando est casta, aut ex habentibus maritos.	And the second is, that you do not find a woman who reveals herself to a physician, when she is chaste, or one of those having husbands.
Tertius est, quia tu non inuenis mulierem bene scientem hanc artem, praecipue operationem cum manu.	The third is, that you do not find a woman well knowing this art, especially the operation with the hand.
Et quartus est longinquitas a loco lapidis: quare indiget sectione profunda, et in illo est timor.	And the fourth is the remoteness of the place of the stone: where it requires a deep incision, and in that there is fear.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad illud, tunc oportet ut accipias mulierem medicam, bene scientem: et parum inuenitur.	What if necessity provokes to that, then it is necessary that you accept a woman physician, well knowing: and she is rarely found.
Si uero priuaris ea, tunc quaere medicum castum, subtilem, et praesenta mulierem obstetricem bene doctam in re mulierum, aut mulierem quae in hac arte innuit partem artis: fac ergo eam praesentem, et praecipue ei, ut faciat totum quod praecipis ei ex inquisitione super lapidem.	If you are deprived of them, then seek a chaste physician, subtle, and present a midwife well taught in the matter of women, or a woman who has begun to learn part of the art: make her therefore present, and command her, that she do all that you command her from the inquiry about the stone.
In primis quod est, ut aspiciat si mulier est uirgo: tunc oportet ut intromittat digitum in anum eius, et quaerat lapidem.	At first what is, to examine if the woman is a virgin: then it is necessary that she insert a finger into her anus, and seek the stone.
Si ergo inuenit ipsum, coartet eum sub digito suo, et tunc praecipe obstetrici, ut intromittat digitum suum in uuluam infirmae, et inquirat super lapidem, postquam ponit manum suam sinistram super uesicam, et comprimit eam compressione bona.	If then he finds it, he constricts it under his finger, and then orders the midwife to insert her finger into the weak woman's vulva, and feels above the stone, after which she places her left hand on the bladder, and presses it with a good compression.
Si ergo inuenit lapidem, tunc oportet ut gradatim moueat eum ab orificio uesicae ad inferiora cum summa uirtutis suae, donec perueniat cum eo ad radicem coxae.	If then he finds the stone, then it is necessary that he moves it gradually from the orifice of the bladder to the lower areas with the greatest strength of his, until he reaches with it to the root of the hip.
Deinde secet super eum apud oppositionem medietatis uuluae apud radicem coxae, ex quacunque parte praeparatur ei, et sentit lapidem in illa parte: et digitus eius non remoueatur a lapide, coartans sub eo: et sit sectio parua in primis.	Then he cuts above it at the opposite of the middle of the vulva at the root of the hip, from whichever side he prepares for it, and feels the stone on that side: and his finger is not removed from the stone, constricting under it: and let the incision be small at first.
Deinde intromittat radium super illam sectionem.	Then he inserts the razor above that incision.
Si ergo sentit lapidem, tunc addat in sectionem secundum quantitatem proportionatam quod lapis egreditur ab ea.	If then he feels the stone, then he adds to the incision a second cut proportional in quantity to what of the stone emerges from it.
Et scias, quod species lapidis sunt multae.	And know that there are many types of stones.
Ex his enim est paruus, et magnus, lenis et asper, longus, et rotundus habens ramos.	For among them is the small and the large, the smooth and the rough, the long and the round having branches.
Scias ergo species eius, ut significetur tibi per hoc super illud quod uis.	Know therefore its species, so that it may be indicated to you by this above what you are using.
Si ergo uincit te sanguis, tunc adde in loco zegi tritum, et tene ipsum hora una, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If then the blood overcomes you, then apply to the place a poultice of toasted and ground, and hold it for one hour, until the bleeding stops.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis: et fac, ut praepares tecum ex instrumentis, quae dixi in extractione lapidis in uiris, ut adiuueris per ea in operatione tua.	Then return to your operation, until the stone emerges: and do, so that you prepare with you from the instruments, which I mentioned in the extraction of the stone from the bladder, so that you may help yourself by them in your operation.
Quod si uincit te fluxus sanguinis, et scis quod expulsio sanguinis est ex arteria quae incisa est: tunc pone puluerem super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis strictura decenti: et non mutes illud: et dimitte lapidem, et non extrahas ipsum.	For if the flow of blood overcomes you, and you know that the expulsion of blood is from the artery which was cut: then put powder on the place, and constrict it with decent stricturing bandages: and do not move it: and leave the stone, and do not extract it.
Fortasse enim morietur mulier infirma.	A weak woman will perhaps die from it.
Deinde cura uulnus.	Then treat the wound.
Cum ergo sedatur acuitas sanguinis post dies, et putrefit locus, tune redi ad operationem tuam, donec egrediatur lapis.	When therefore the sharpness of the blood is satiated after some days, and the place becomes putrid, then return to your operation, until the stone comes out.
¶ De sectione suiper Herniam aquosam.	On the cutting of a watery hernia.
Caput LXII.	Chapter 62.
Ramex aquosa non est, nisi aggregatio humiditatis in sifac albo, quod est sub cute testiculi continente ouum: et nominatur sifac.	A watery collection is not a true hernia, unless it be an aggregation of humidity in the white vascular covering that is under the skin of the testicle containing the egg: and it is named a vascular covering.
Et quandoque est in panniculo proprio sibi, quem praeparauit ei natura in parte oui, donec putetur: quod est ouum aliud, et est cutis testiculi inter sifac album, quod diximus: et non fit illud nisi raro.	And sometimes it is in its own proper membrane, which nature has prepared for it in the part of the egg, until it becomes putrid: which is another egg, and is a skin of the testicle between the white vascular covering that we spoke of: and this does not happen except rarely.
Et generatio quidem huius ramicis, est ex debilitate quae accidit testiculis: quare effunditur ad eos haec materia.	And the generation of this watery collection is from a weakness that happens to the testicles: for which reason this material flows out to them.
Et quandoque accidit ex percussione super testiculos.	And sometimes it happens from a blow on the testicles.
Et haec humiditas est habens colores multos.	And this humidity has many colors.
Aut enim est color eius decliuis ad citrinitatem, aut est sanguineus rubeus, aut faeculentus, niger, aut est aquosus albus, et est illud quod est plus.	For it is either of a yellowish color, or it is a bloody red, or feculent, black, or it is a watery white, and this is the one that is most.
Et signa quibus scitur ubi sit aggregatio aquae, sunt ista.	And the signs by which it is known where the collection of water is, are these.
Nam si est in sifac albo quod diximus, tunc apostema est rotundum ad longitudinem parumper sicut figura oui: et non apparet testiculus, quoniam humiditas continet eum ab omni parte.	For if it is in the white vascular covering that we spoke of, then the swelling is round in length for a while just like the shape of an egg: and the testicle does not appear, because the humidity contains it on every side.
Et si est humiditas in panniculo proprio sibi, tunc apostema est rotundum cum parte oui, et propter hoc extimat homo quia est ouum aliud.	And if it is humidity in its own proper membrane, then the swelling is round with a part of the egg, and because of this a man thinks that it is another egg.
Et si humiditas est inter cutem testiculorum et sifac album, tunc cadit sub sensu.	And if the humidity is between the skin of the testicles and the white vascular covering, then it falls under the sense.
Quando ergo uis cognitionem coloris humiditatis, tunc experire colorem humiditatis in apostemate cum Intromisso quadrato, cuius forma praecessit.	When I apply my knowledge of the colour of humidity, then I test the colour of humidity in the apostema with the square introversion, whose shape precedes.
Secundum illud ergo quod egreditur in uestigio Intromissi, iudica de illo quod est inter ipsum.	According to that which appears in the trace of the Introversion, I judge from that which is between it.
Cum ergo uenimus ad curationem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, ut phlebotometur si possibile est ei illud, et uides corpus eius plenum.	When we proceed to a cure with iron, then it is necessary to prescribe to the weak, that they should be bled if possible for them, and you see his body full.
Deinde resupinetur super dorsum suum super rem altam parum, et pone sub eo pannos multos.	Then he should be placed on his back on something high and a little elevated, and many cloths should be put under him.
Deinde sede tu super sinistram eius, et praecipe ministro, ut sedeat a dextra eius, qui extendat uirgam eius ad unum duorum laterum cutis testiculorum, et ad partem mirach uentris.	Then sit on his left side, and instruct the assistant to sit on his right side, who should stretch out his arm to one of the two sides of the skin of the testicles, and to the region of the navel.
Deinde accipe spatumile latum, et seca cutem testiculorum ex medio per longitudinem, usque prope pectinem: et fiat sectio secundum rectitudinem aequedistantis lineae quae diuidit cutem testiculorum, donec perueniat ad sifac album comprehendens: et excoria ipsum et obserua, uel caue ex hoc, ut seces ipsum: et sit excoriatio tua qua ipsum excorias, ex parte quae suspenditur cum ouo plus: et subtiliter scrutare cum excoriatione secundum quantitatem quod tibi possibile est.	Then take a broad spatula, and cut the skin of the testicles in the middle along the length, up to near the breast; and let the incision be according to the rectitude of the equidistant line which divides the skin of the testicles, until it reaches the white substance that comprehends; and cut out this and observe, or take care lest you cut from hence, that you cut it; and your cutting should be where it is suspended with the egg more: and subtly examine with the cutting according to the quantity that is possible for you.
Deinde perfora sifac plenum aqua perforatione ampla, et extrahe totam aquam.	Then pierce the full watery substance with a wide piercing, and extract all the water.
Deinde separa inter duo labia sectionis cum uncinis, et extende sifac ad superiora, et non tangas cutem testiculorum comprehendentem: et incide sifac qualitercunque est possibile tibi incidere ipsum, aut cum totalitate sua, aut frustatim, praecipue latus eius subtile.	Then separate between the two lips of the incision with forceps, and stretch the watery substance upwards, and do not touch the skin of the testicles that comprehends; and cut the watery substance as much as it is possible for you to cut it, or with its entirety, or in a piece, especially the broad subtle part.
Nam si tu non exquisite perscrutaris, in incisione eius non fit securitas, quin aqua redeat.	For if you do not carefully and thoroughly examine in the incision, there will be no security, lest the water flow back.
Si autem procedit ouum exterius a cute sua in hora operationis tuae: tunc quando compleueris sectionem sifac, reduc ipsum.	If however the egg proceeds outward from its skin during the time of your operation: then when you have completed the incision of the womb, reduce it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cutis testiculorum cum sutura.	Then bring together the two lips of the skin of the testicles with a suture.
Deinde cura ipsum sicut reliqua uulnera, donec sanetur.	Then cure it as the remaining wounds, until it is healed.
Quod si inuenis ouum corruptum ex nigredine alia, tunc oportet ut liges uasa, quae sunt suspensorium, timens fluxum sanguinis.	What if you find the egg corrupted by blackness of another kind, then it is necessary that you tie the vessels, which are the suspensors, fearing a flow of blood.
Deinde abscinde testiculum cum suspensorio, et extrahe ouum: postea cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	Then cut off the testicle with its suspensor, and extract the egg: afterwards cure it with what we have said.
Si uero aqua est aggregata in duabus partibus, tunc scias quia sunt duae ramices: seca ergo partem aliam secundum quod fecisti in altera aequaliter.	If indeed water is collected in the two parts, then know that there are two pipes: therefore cut the other part equally according to what you have done in the other.
Et si aequatur tibi, ut sit operatio una, tunc fac: deinde absterge sanguinem.	And if it is equal to you, that there be one operation, then do it: afterwards wipe away the blood.
Et intromitte in sectiones lanam submersam in oleo, aut in oleo rosato: et pone deforis lanam aliam quam submersisti in uino et oleo, et expande eam super duos testiculos, et mirach uentris: et pone desuper pannos duplicatos, et sunt puluilli: et liga eos desuper cum ligamento, quod est habens sex secundum hanc formam.	And insert into the incisions a thread soaked in oil, or in rose oil: and put on the dressing a thread which you have soaked in wine and oil, and spread it over the two testicles, and the navel: and put above double cloths, and they are poultices: and tie them above with a bandage, which has six according to this form.
Deinde sumantur duo panni, et suantur, et impleantur la na carminata, secundum hanc similitudinem: et fiant extremitates quibus premitur ex coto, aut lana humida: et aggregentur cum strictura in lumbari bracharum: et una extremitatum accipiat super anum usque ad dorsum, et secunda accipiat ad partem pectinis: et duae extremitates super duas coxas inferius, et duae extremitates aliae super duo inguina, et aggregetur strictura tota in lumbari bracharum.	Then let two cloths be taken, and they be sewn, and filled with medicated thread, according to this likeness: and let the extremities be made which are pressed from a cot, or a wet thread: and let them be tied with a bandage in the groin of the arms: and one extremity let it reach above the thigh up to the back, and the second let it reach to the part of the breast: and two extremities above the two hips below, and two other extremities above the two groins, and all the bandage be tied in the groin of the arms.
Et, quandoque artificialiter medicatur haec ramex cum cauterio loco sectionis cum ferro: et est, ut accipias cauterium cultellare subtile, et seces cum eo cutem testiculorum: et est ignitum, secundum quod narrauimus: donec quando detegitur sifac album continens aquam: tunc accipe cauterium, secundum hanc formam.	And when this ramex is treated artificially with a cautery at the place of the section with iron; and it is, that you take a sharp cautery knife, and cut the skin of the testicles; and it is ignited, according to what we have narrated: until when there appears a white scab containing water: then take the cautery, according to this form.
Assimilatur literae graecae.	The Greek letters are absorbed.
Deinde perfora cum eo illud sifac, et est ignitum, donec egrediatur humiditas tota.	Then puncture that scab with it, and it is ignited, until all moisture comes out.
Deinde extende sifac cum uncinis, et excoria cum cauterio subtili ignito, et incide ipsum secundum quod possibile est tibi, donec eradices totum eius.	Then stretch the scab with forceps, and scrape it with a sharp ignited cautery, and cut it according to what is possible for you, until you eradicate the whole of it.
Et caue ex ouo, ne tangat ipsum ignis.	And beware lest the fire touch it.
Et scias, quod haec operatio est saluior, et longinquior a fluxu sanguinis, et melior quam operatio cum sectione.	And know that this operation is safer, and less inclined to a flow of blood, and better than the operation with a section.
Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit in hora sectionis, aut in hora cauterii apostema calidum, aut fluxus sanguinis, aut aliquid aliud: tunc oportet ut cures quod contrarietatem tibi facit ex illo cum curatione quae conuenit ei, secundum quod praemissum est.	If indeed an adverse condition makes itself known to you at the time of the section, or at the time of the cautery, whether it be a hot aposteme, or a flow of blood, or something else: then it is necessary that you treat that which makes the adverse condition known to you from that with a cure which is suitable for it, according to what has been previously stated.
Si autem infirmus est timidus, et non expectat super hanc operationem, propter horribilitatem suam: tunc administra perforationem secundum quod ego narro illud: et est.	If however he is weak and timid, and does not look forward to this operation, because of its horror: then administer the puncture according to what I have narrated it to be.
Quando certificatur tibi apud te per illud quod diximus de significationibus, quod ramex est aquosa: tunc oportet quod facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	When it is confirmed to you by that which we have spoken of concerning the signs, that the ramex is watery: then it is necessary that you make the weak person sit on an elevated seat.
Deinde perfora apostema in inferiori parte sui cum spatumili lato: et pone perforationem secundum longitudinem corporis, et sit apertio ampla, donec currat aqua tota.	Then puncture the aposteme in its lower part with a broad spatula: and put the puncture according to the length of the body, and let it be wide open, until all the water runs out.
Deinde pone super locum cotum, et liga ipsum, et dimitte ipsum ut currat residuum aquae: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then put a dressing on the place of the cut, and bind it, and let it stay so that the remainder of the water runs out: then treat it, until the wound is healed.
Si autem contrarietas sit egressioni aquae in hora qua perforas ipsam: et non sit illud nisi propterea, quia panniculus albus contrarietatem facit in orificio uulneris, et prohibet exitum aquae: tunc oportet ut intromittas pennam in uulnus, aut instrumentum cum quo extrahitur aqua hydropicorum, cuius forma praecessit: aut adde in operatione uulneris parumper.	If however the blockage is an obstacle to the exit of water at the time when you perforate it: and it is not except on account of that, because the white membrane makes a blockage in the opening of the wound, and prohibits the exit of water: then it is necessary that you insert a feather into the wound, or an instrument with which water of dropsy is extracted, whose form has preceded: or add for a short time in the operation of the wound.
Et scias, quod aqua redit, et aggregatur post sex menses, aut circiter eos.	And you should know that the water returns and accumulates after six months, or around that time.
Cum ergo aggregatur, tunc pertoretur secundum eundem modum, et pertransibit infirmus dies suos.	When therefore it accumulates, then it should be tapped according to the same method, and the weak days will pass.
¶ De cura Ramicis carnosae.	On the treatment of a fleshy ulcer.
Caput LXIII.	Chapter 63.
Scias, quod in sectione super hanc Ramicem, est ex timore perducente ad perniciem in pluribus dispositionibus.	You should know that in the incision above this ulcer, there is a fear of inducing destruction in many conditions.
Quapropter uidetur mihi eius dimissio saluari ex ea.	Wherefore it seems to me that its neglect is beneficial for its healing.
Et ego sum rememorans operationem in ea, et species apostematis.	And I recall the operation on it, and the appearance of an apostema.
Dico ergo, quod accidunt apostemata multa in corporibus, ex quibus componuntur testiculi: et fit illud ex caussis multis, scilicet.	I say therefore, that many gatherings occur in the bodies, from which the testicles are composed: and this happens for many reasons.
Aut ex superfluitate acuta, uel acri, quae effunditur ad testiculos.	Or from an excess of sharp or acidic humor, which flows to the testicles.
Aut ex percussione.	Or from a blow.
Et est color apostematis secundum colorem corporis, et non inuenitur ei dolor: et est apostema graue.	And the color of the gathering is according to the color of the body, and no pain is found in it: and it is a serious gathering.
Et fortasse est apostema lapideum, cuius color est fuscus, et non est sensus ei.	And perhaps it is a stone-like gathering, whose color is dark, and there is no sensation in it.
Et quandoque fit ex nodatione arteriarum, et inflatione earum: sicut iam praecessit eius rememoratio: aut ex inflatione uenarum.	And sometimes it happens from the knotting of the arteries, and their swelling: as I have already mentioned before: or from the swelling of the veins.
Quod ergo est ex eis ex inflatione arteriarum, cognoscitur per dispositionem apostematis, quando comprimis ipsum digitis tuis.	That which is therefore from the swelling of the arteries, is recognized by the condition of the gathering, when you press it with your fingers.
Et non oportet ut tangas ipsum prorsus.	And it is not proper to touch it directly.
Illud uero quod fit ex inflatione uenarum, non dispergitur ex eo aliquid apud compressionem cum digitis.	That which is made from the inflation of veins is not dispersed from it by compression with the fingers.
Et iam possibile est, quod super hanc speciem fiat sectio, et super reliquas carnes: et est, ut seces cutem testiculorum.	And now it is possible that a section on this species is made and on the rest of the flesh and it is as one cuts the skin of the testicles.
Deinde extende ouum ad sursum, et extrahe ipsum cum sifach albo: et libera suspensorium ex uasis, et liga uasa: et incide suspensorium postquam tu liberas ipsum ab omni parte ex partibus oui.	Then extend the egg upwards, and extract it with the white siftach: and free the suspensor from the vessels, and tie up the vessels: and cut the suspensor after you have freed it from every part of the parts of the egg.
Si ergo ouum consolidatum est cum illis carnibus natis, tunc oportet ut attrahas ouum, et incidas ipsum.	If then the egg is consolidated with those born flesh, then it is proper that you should pull the egg and cut it.
Et si adhaerentia est inter aliquid ex siphaket, aut in eo quod est inter uasa: tunc oportet ut liberes totam illam adhaerentiam, et incidas eam incisione rotunda.	And if an adhesion is between any of the siphacet or in that which is between the vessels: then it is proper that you free the whole of that adhesion, and cut it with a round incision.
Si autem est natiuitas carnis in loco adhaerentiae quae est retro: tunc oportet ut incidas totum eius, et extrahas ouum, sicut diximus.	If however there is a nativity of flesh in the place of adhesion which is behind: then it is proper that you cut the whole of it, and extract the egg, as we have said.
Cum ergo completur operatio tua, tnnc imple uulnus in lana infusa in oleo rosato, et uino: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When therefore your operation is completed, then fill the wound with wool infused in rose oil and wine: afterwards cure it with the rest of the treatment, until it is healed.
¶ De cura Ramicis, quae est cum Vite.	On the treatment of Varices, which is with Veins.
Caput LXIIII.	Chapter 64.
Uitis est apostema inuolutum quadam inuolutione, simile botro, cum mollificatione testiculorum: et fit difficilis super infirmum motus et exercitium, et deambulatio.	Uitis is an unresolved aposteme, which occurs with a certain wrapping, similar to a boil, with softening of the testicles: and it makes difficult movement and exercise on the infirm, and walking.
Et in curatione huius aegritudinis est ex timore, propter illud cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And in the cure of this sickness is fear, because of that which has preceded it, the memory remains.
Verum oportet, ut dicamus operationem in ea secundum quod fecerunt primi.	It is true that we should say the operation on it according to what the first ones did.
Dico ergo, quod oportet ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem eleuatam.	I say therefore, that it is proper to make the infirm person sit on an elevated seat.
Deinde impelle suspensorium testiculorum ad inferiora.	Then strike the suspension of the testicles to the lower parts.
Deinde tene cutem testiculorum cum digitis tuis, cum uasis quae sunt propinqua uirgae: et teneat ea minister alius, et extendat ea extensione uehementi.	Then hold the skin of the testicles with your fingers, with the instruments that are nearest to the rod: and let another servant hold them, and let him stretch them with a vigorous stretching.
Deinde incide cum spatumili lato acuto sectione transuersa in directo uasorum, donec detegantur uasa.	Then cut with a broad sharp spatula a transverse section in the direction of the vessels, until the vessels are exposed.
Deinde excoria ab omni parte, sicut diximus tibi in extractione Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then scratch away from every part, as we have told you in the extraction of the arteries that are in the temples.
Postea fige in eis acum in qua sit filum duplum, et liga ipsum in primo locorum quibus accidunt Vites: et liga ipsum iterum in ultimo eorum.	Afterwards fix in them a needle in which is a double thread, and tie it in the first places to which the ties occur: and tie it again at the last of them.
Deinde seca ea in media sectione recta secundum longitudinem corporis, et extrahe quod aggregatur ex humiditatibus faeculentis corruptis.	Then cut it in a straight section according to the length of the body, and extract what is gathered from foul corrupted humors.
Deinde cura uulnus cum curatione reliquorum uulnerum, in quibus uis generari saniem, ut cadant uasa quae nutriunt unum testiculorum.	Then treat the wound with the treatment of other wounds, in which it is customary to generate a sanative, so that the vessels which nourish one of the testicles fall.
Non est enim malum per illud.	For it is not an evil through that.
Si autem accidat Vitis omnibus uasis, tunc oportet ut extrahantur propter hoc testiculi cum uasis: ut non priuetur ouum nutrimento, propter incisionem, et tabescat, uel arescat, et non sit iuuamentum cum eis.	If however the vessel occurs to all the vessels, then it is necessary that the testicles with the vessels be extracted for this: so that the ovum is not deprived of nourishment, on account of the incision, and wither, or dry up, and is not a help with them.
¶ De cura Ramicis intestinalis.	Of the treatment of Intestinal hernias.
Caput LXV.	Chapter 65.
Euentus huius Ramicis est ex sectione, quae accidit in sifach extenso super uentrem in parte inguinum ex mirach uentris.	The coming out of this hernia is from a section, which occurs in the siphac extended above the navel on the groin side from the middle of the navel.
Quare descendunt intestina ex illa Ruptura ad unum testiculorum.	Why the intestines come down from that rupture to one of the testicles.
Et haec Ruptura est aut ex sifach, aut extensione eius.	And this rupture is either from the siphac or from its extension.
Et accidunt istae duae species ex caussis multis: aut ex percussione, aut saltu, aut clamore, aut eleuatione rei grauis, et similibus.	And these two kinds occur from many causes: either from a blow, or a jump, or a shout, or the lifting of a heavy thing, and similar things.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	And the sign is when it is from the extension of the wrist.
